title: 103_hr1948
content: The Act titled "Former Soviet Union Nuclear Threat Reduction Act of 1993" aims to reduce the nuclear threat in the former Soviet Union through a specific program. The President will establish a program to reduce environmental and national security threats from nuclear facilities in Belarus, Kazakhstan, Russia, and Ukraine. Assistance will be provided to accelerate the retirement of plutonium production facilities, close Chernobyl-type reactors, and promote alternative energy sources and energy conservation measures. The President's program aims to reduce environmental and national security threats from nuclear facilities in Belarus, Kazakhstan, Russia, and Ukraine. It includes promoting energy conservation measures, cleaning up nuclear contaminated sites, establishing training programs for environmental restoration, deactivating nuclear-powered submarines, storing and disposing of radioactive materials, and strengthening nuclear materials security systems. Technical working groups will be established for these purposes. The President will establish technical working groups with former Soviet Union states and other nations capable of producing nuclear weapons material within 180 days of this Act's enactment. This is in line with the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1993. The President will establish technical working groups with former Soviet Union states and other nations capable of producing nuclear weapons material within 180 days of this Act's enactment, in line with the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1993. Certification requirements will be implemented. The President must certify to Congress that a country seeking assistance meets specific criteria, including ratifying START I, acceding to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, and meeting eligibility requirements under certain acts. The curr_chunk focuses on supporting the operation or improvement of plants for chemical separation of plutonium from fission products in spent nuclear fuel. The curr_chunk focuses on reporting requirements related to the operation or improvement of plants for chemical separation of plutonium from fission products in spent nuclear fuel. The reporting requirements under the Former Soviet Union Demilitarization Act of 1992 and the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1993 apply to the obligation or use of funds for the program established under section 2(a). Quarterly reports on program activities must be submitted to Congress as per specified timelines. The Demilitarization Act of 1992 requires the President to report to Congress on actions taken to comply with nuclear stockpile weapons arrangements outlined in the Senate resolution of ratification of START I. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATION. The Office of Defense Programs or the Office of Intelligence and National Security of the Department of Energy will oversee the program established under section 2(a) in coordination with other Federal agencies. The President will coordinate this program with other assistance programs for the former Soviet Union. SEC. 6. FUNDING. The President will transfer up to $500,000,000 from prior Department of Energy appropriations for national security programs to carry out section 2(a).
